Award.AwardTitle: How poverty impacts brain and language development: Understanding the vocabulary gap

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the US, over 31 million children (42%) are from low socioeconomic status (SES) homes. On average these children have significantly smaller vocabularies than their middle SES peers. This vocabulary gap appears early in development, increases during the school years and has life-long academic and economic implications. Although research has identified some possible reasons for lower vocabulary in low SES toddlers, it is not clear how or why the deficit continues to increase during the school years. The present project will study how well-documented SES differences in semantic knowledge, reading abilities and working memory may contribute to word learning deficits at the behavioral and brain levels in school-aged children. The outcomes of this research will help to identify directions for intervention to increase the likelihood of academic success within this at-risk population.

This project will use a relatively new analysis technique, Time Frequency Analysis, to study changes in electrophysiological processes of school-aged children (8-15 years) as they learn new words. These neuronal responses will be studied in relation to children's word learning abilities, family background (mother's level of education and needs-to-income ratio) and cognitive abilities (reading abilities, vocabulary and working memory). In this way, the proposed work will clarify the mechanisms by which SES influences the behavioral and neural processes contributing to children's word learning during the school years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the US, over 31 million children (42%) are from low socioeconomic status (SES) homes. On average these children have significantly smaller vocabularies than their middle SES peers. It is well established that this vocabulary gap appears early in development and has life-long academic and economic implications. What is less understood, and was the focus of our project, is why SES gap in vocabulary knowledge expands during the school years when a formal learning environment should, in theory, help level the playing field. We used both neuroimaging (EEG) and behavioral measures to address these questions.   

Intellectual Merit. This topic covers a range of disciplines including language development and developmental cognitive neuroscience. Here we highlight how some of our more prominent findings impact those fields.

Related to language development, we found that (1) children from lower SES homes learn fewer words than their higher SES peers in a word learning from context task and (2) vocabulary, not reading comprehension mediates this relationship between SES and word learning. These findings indicate that early differences in vocabulary growth related to home environment may snowball making future learning more difficult for children from low SES homes. Further, while schools tend to focus on reading comprehension as a primary pathway to vocabulary growth, our findings indicate something more foundational related to vocabulary knowledge may be the key. On the positive side, the fact that learning underlies these differences indicates there is potential for targeted and effective school based interventions to offset these differences.

Related to developmental cognitive neuroscience, we found that (1) the N400, a neural marker of word learning, attenuates to words that are being learned in children, just as it does in adults, however,  (2) the N400 response is robust in children from higher SES homes, but not those from lower SES homes during the word learning task. This supports and extends upon findings about how a childhood in a low SES home can lead to differences or at least more variability in children?s neural structure and/or function. Further, we found that (3) children from low SES homes exhibit differences in resting state EEG compare to higher SES peers and these differences correspond to differences in working memory and vocabulary. This finding again supports the idea that a childhood in a low SES home may relate to differences in brain structure and function, but expands upon them by showing the unique effects on distinct cognitive outcomes. Finally, (4) when studying neural oscillations of the EEG we found that children from higher SES homes tend to exhibit differences in the theta (4-8Hz) and beta (13-30Hz) ranges during word learning, which traditionally relate to word retrieval and sentence level integration, while children from low SES homes rely more heavily on alpha (9-12Hz), which often corresponds to more general cognitive processes. These findings provide some insight into the types of interventions that might be most effective for helping children from low SES homes more effectively take advantage of everyday word learning opportunities.

Together these findings clarify why a childhood in a low SES environment has long term implications for future language learning, as well as what aspects are most impacted so that future interventions can be more targeted and cost effective.

Broader Impacts. Through this award we have provided academic training in fields of language science, developmental psychology and cognitive neuroscience to 76 students, ranging from high school through PhD level, who have had hands on experiences collecting, analyzing and disseminating findings from this project. Our findings have been widely distributed in scientific writings and conferences. Specifically, we have published 4 papers in top ranked, peer-review academic journal articles, with 2 currently under review, and multiple in progress. We have presented 7 talks at national and international conferences, 16 posters at national and international conferences (most by student scientists),  5 presentations to the wider community including summer camps for high school girls who are likely to be the first in their families to attend college. Further, the data from this study has been used in 2 graduate student theses and 4 undergraduate research awards. These findings also have important implications for groups traditional underrepresented in science because in the US children from low SES homes often have limited opportunities for academic and economic success. Given the impact of vocabulary on long-term academic achievement, understanding and eventually changing the factors underlying this disparity is essential to improving the education, lifelong well-being, and economic competitiveness of these populations.
